author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: ‘Just for Us’ Reaches Across the Chasm
description: The return of this brisk, smart provocation of a monologue is a cheering development, all the more so because it’s a belly-laugh funny show.
content: On a narrow, curving street in the West Village of Manhattan, a sign of hope: A production that went dark just before Christmas, as the Omicron variant descended on the city, has opened back up at the Cherry Lane Theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed’s Policy Pivot May Prove Late and Abrupt, Critics Fret
description: The Federal Reserve is still buying bonds as prices surge. Some praise the central bank’s continuing policy pivot; others ask if it was fast enough.
content: The Federal Reserve has moved at warp speed by central banking standards over the past six months as it prepares to lean against a surge in prices: first slowing its economy-stoking bond purchases, then deciding to end that buying program earlier and finally signaling that interest rate increases are coming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Schneider
title: After Urban Flight, Corporate Campuses Add a Taste of the City
description: Suburban headquarters are being redesigned to add more amenities that will integrate better with their communities and attract the skilled workers.
content: TYSONS, Va. — After World War II, corporations moved to exclusive gated suburban campuses to escape traffic, crowds and big-city clamor. Now companies are designing a little city hubbub back into suburban headquarters by adding shops, restaurants, hotels, residences and public parks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: How to Survive When Stocks Behave Badly
description: The stock market’s swings have been startling. Unfortunately, it’s wise to prepare for much worse.
content: Where is the stock market heading? That can be an urgent question — especially when you’re losing money in a fickle market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Watch 5 Standout Performances From Winter Jazzfest
description: Digital broadcasts took the place of live shows this year, and artists from around the globe participated in this annual check-in on the state of the music.
content: For improvising musicians across New York, Winter Jazzfest’s return to live stages this month might have brought a whiff of near normalcy — not to mention more than 100 packed gigs in the span of just over a week — to a much-beleaguered scene. For audiences, it would have been a moment to dive back in at the deep end: skipping around, from clubs to theaters to makeshift stages, hearing how jazz’s creative winds have shifted over the past two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Oshetsky
title: These Stories Will Defy All Your Expectations
description: New collections by Bernard MacLaverty, Gwen E. Kirby, Gish Jen and Morgan Thomas.
content: BLANK PAGES And Other StoriesBy Bernard MacLaverty 261 pp. Norton. $26.95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: ‘Eating to Extinction’ Is a Celebration of Rare Foods and a Warning About the Future
description: To underscore the importance of food diversity, Dan Saladino traveled the world to showcase some of the treasures we risk losing.
content: Citrus is a sex-positive genus. All of our commercially grown citrus varieties derive from three ancestors — the mandarin, the pomelo and the citron — that were (and are) capable of being fertilized by one another’s pollen, a flexibility that has brought us limes, oranges and grapefruits. Add to this fiesta of gene-swapping a propensity for mutation, and you can end up with the clementine — which a farmer in 19th-century Algeria spotted growing on a branch of his mandarin tree, tasted and presumably thought, “We’ve got a winner.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Alec Baldwin Seeks Dismissal of ‘Rust’ Lawsuit
description: The suit was filed by a script supervisor who was just feet away from the film’s cinematographer when the actor fatally shot her on the set.
content: Lawyers for the actor Alec Baldwin and other producers behind the film “Rust” filed a motion on Monday seeking to dismiss a lawsuit filed by the movie’s script supervisor, who was feet away from the actor on the movie set in New Mexico when he fatally shot a cinematographer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Mena, From Victoria Blamey, Opens in TriBeCa
description: A second location of a Middle Eastern favorite, a wine bar in the basement of Peasant, and more restaurant news.
content: “It’s hard to believe,” said Victoria Blamey, the chef who, for years, has earned praise at places like Chumley’s and Gotham Bar & Grill, and is finally opening her own restaurant. Close observers of the New York scene will also know the Chilean-born chef, 42, from her pop-ups at Blue Hill at Stone Barns, the Mayflower Inn in Washington, Conn., and Fulgurances Laundromat in Brooklyn. She describes her new restaurant, named for her great-aunt, as “airy, bright and very feminine” with white walls, banquettes upholstered in cobalt blue and brass fixtures. It’s not easy to nail down her food, which will reflect her native Chile, known for its seafood, as well as her experiences cooking in New York, Spain and Australia. “People might have no idea what to expect from Chilean food, but there will be elements of it,” she said. Cholgas secas, a Chilean dried mussel dish that she prepared during her stay at Blue Hill, are on the menu. Seaweeds, which are popular in Chile, garnish several preparations, including oysters with seaweed gremolata. She is also producing dishes like Japanese sardines with mayonnaise potato and peppers, mussels with onion glaze, squab with buckwheat honey and fermented radicchio, monkfish with wakame and black quinoa, and a winter Pavlova dessert with angel hair squash, citron confit and citrus curd. Her executive sous chef, Daniel Garcia, was at Crown Shy and NoMad, and the junior sous chef, Maggie Paradis, worked with her at Gotham Bar & Grill. The wine list pays attention to organic and biodynamic producers, especially from Chile. (Opens Thursday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $8.425 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Dozens Are Reported Missing After Boat Capsizes Off Florida Coast
description: The boat, which left the Bahamas on Saturday with 40 people on board, was most likely part of a “human smuggling venture,” the Coast Guard said. One passenger was rescued.
content: The U.S. Coast Guard said late Tuesday that it would search through the night for 39 people who went missing days earlier after a boat carrying them from the Bahamas capsized off the Atlantic coast of Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What Are Your Local Vacation Recommendations?
description: We’re asking readers for great getaways.
content: The past two years have taught us a few things about traveling during a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: An Unknown Civil Servant May Determine Boris Johnson’s Fate
description: Sue Gray, who oversees the British government’s ethics inquiries, will deliver a report on Downing Street parties that could topple the prime minister.
content: LONDON — With years of experience in the higher reaches of Britain’s civil service, including overseeing government ethics investigations, Sue Gray has been called the most powerful person Britons had never heard of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: How the Air Fryer Crisped Its Way Into America’s Heart
description: Though the device is sold as a way to make foods crunchy without deep-frying, home cooks have put it to countless other uses — and fed a billion-dollar business.
content: A year ago, Rebecca Abbott, a food photographer and blogger in Mesa, Ariz., bought her first air fryer to develop recipes for a client’s blog. She started with the usual air-fryer specialties, frozen pizza rolls and tater tots, but it wasn’t long until she realized that her model could make pretty much anything she wanted. Four months later, she was stunned when her homemade cheesecake emerged from the device, baked to perfection in 20 minutes with no cracks or dips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Stop Asking Hilary Duff Who the Father Is
description: In an interview, the actress and singer discussed her wide-ranging career and “How I Met Your Father,” her new sitcom reboot on Hulu.
content: The girl next door has a new apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hickley
title: Jehovah’s Witnesses Sue German Museum for Archive of Nazi-Era Abuses
description: The archive documents the lives and suffering of the Kusserow family, who were among many from the religious group to be persecuted by the Nazis because of their faith.
content: The Jehovah’s Witnesses, a pacifist religious group, are pursuing legal action against the German government to claim a family archive that documents the Nazis’ persecution of the Christian denomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Touring Through Omicron: Broadway Shows Hit Bumps on the Road
description: Audiences are enthusiastic, but casts are vulnerable, as companies travel from city to city, trying to revive a key part of the theater economy.
content: The “Mean Girls” tour made it to Oklahoma before it was knocked out by the coronavirus. At first, the production had been able to keep going by flying in alumni from its Broadway run, but ultimately the number of company members testing positive was just too high, so earlier this month the show decided to cancel its remaining shows in Tulsa, and then postponed the runs that would have followed in two Wisconsin cities, Madison and Appleton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller and Marc Santora
title: Omicron Offers Hope Pandemic Could Stabilize, W.H.O. Official Says.
description: The rapid spread of the variant means far more people will have some immunity, at least for now, which might bode well this year for highly vaccinated countries in Europe.
content: The astonishing spread of the Omicron variant could help set the stage for the pandemic to transition from overwhelming to manageable in Europe this year, a top health official said on Monday, potentially offering the world a glimpse at how countries can ease restrictions while keeping the virus at bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf and Ben Hubbard
title: As Islamic State Resurges, U.S. Is Drawn Back Into the Fray
description: “ISIS is not over”: Attacks in Syria and Iraq make clear that the militants have lost neither their will to fight nor their ability to do so.
content: BAGHDAD, Iraq — An audacious attack on a prison housing thousands of former ISIS fighters in Syria. A series of strikes against military forces in neighboring Iraq. And a horrific video harking back to the grimmest days of the insurgency that showed the beheading of an Iraqi police officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Cardi B Awarded $4 Million in Libel Lawsuit Against Celebrity Gossip Blogger
description: The rapper sued the YouTuber Tasha K in 2019 after she posted a series of videos claiming that Cardi B was a prostitute.
content: A federal jury awarded the rapper Cardi B around $4 million in a libel lawsuit against a celebrity gossip blogger who had posted videos in 2018 claiming that she was a prostitute who had contracted sexually transmitted infections and used cocaine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Why Not Copy YouTube’s Good Idea?
description: Online creators make the content that entertains and informs us, and they want to share in the riches.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Sydney Harper, Rob Szypko, Rachelle Bonja, Rikki Novetsky, M.J. Davis Lin, Anita Badejo, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Corey Schreppel
title: How Partying Could Be Boris Johnson’s Undoing
description: The British prime minister is engulfed in a scandal over parties held at his home and office during lockdown. Could this spell the end of his premiership?
content: At the end of November last year, The Daily Mirror, a British tabloid, carried a story about parties held at 10 Downing Street, where British prime ministers live and work, at a time when the rest of the nation was in strict lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Karen Zraick
title: How Do You Say Kyiv? It Can Be Hard for English Speakers.
description: “When I see American media, it’s always different, it’s always new, always a surprise,” said a teacher of Ukrainian and Russian languages.
content: It is not the most important question regarding the international maelstrom currently brewing in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Michael Avenatti Will Represent Himself During Remainder of His Trial
description: Mr. Avenatti is accused of impersonating and defrauding Stormy Daniels when he served as her lawyer. The decision means he is likely to cross-examine her during his trial.
content: Michael Avenatti, the brash lawyer who represented the pornographic film actress Stormy Daniels in a dispute with then-President Donald J. Trump, seized center stage at his criminal trial on Tuesday, suddenly announcing that he wanted to act as his own lawyer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Compartment No. 6’ Review: Strangers on a Russian Train
description: A young Finnish woman embarks on a journey of self-discovery that takes her (and you) through richly detailed and surprising terrain.
content: When the heroine in “Compartment No. 6” gets into a car with a guy who has been giving her nothing but grief, you may silently shriek: What is she thinking? You may also judge her for what looks like a bad decision or damn the filmmaker for putting yet another woman in hackneyed straits. Vulnerable women and dangerous men are clichés, but they’re also turned on their heads in this smart, emotionally nuanced film that rarely goes where you expect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Clement
title: A Border Novel Depicts the Haunting Landscapes of the ‘Disappeared’
description: Set along the frontier between the United States and Mexico, “Perpetual West,” by Mesha Maren, unfolds in a culture where the prospect of disappearance and death is a constant fear.
content: PERPETUAL WESTBy Mesha Maren
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Peter Dinklage Calls Disney’s ‘Snow White’ Remake ‘Backward’
description: The actor said on a podcast that he was stunned to learn that “Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs” would be made into a live-action film. Disney said Tuesday that it was “consulting with members of the dwarfism community.”
content: On Monday’s episode of Marc Maron’s “WTF” podcast, the “Game of Thrones” star Peter Dinklage said he was stunned to learn that Disney was doing a live-action remake of the 1937 animated film “Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs” — and more so, that Disney was proud to announce that it had cast a Latina actress, Rachel Zegler (“West Side Story”), as the lead.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Portraits of Relief
description: Waves of borrowers in the federal Public Service Loan Forgiveness program are seeing their debts go to zero. Here’s how six of them finally got there.
content: When the Department of Education announced a plan to fix many hellish problems with its Public Service Loan Forgiveness program, hundreds of thousands of beleaguered borrowers held their breath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: A police inquiry into Downing Street gatherings puts more pressure on Boris Johnson.
description: LONDON — The British police have opened an investigation into parties held at 10 Downing Street and other government offices during a coronavirus lockdown, an ominous development for Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who is trying to hold off a career-threatening challenge over his handling of the scandal.
content: LONDON — The British police have opened an investigation into parties held at 10 Downing Street and other government offices during a coronavirus lockdown, an ominous development for Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who is trying to hold off a career-threatening challenge over his handling of the scandal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘When The Times First Says It, This Twitter Bot Tracks It’
description: In this lesson, students will consider what the @NYT_first_said account can tell us about the evolution of language.
content: Featured Article: “When The Times First Says It, This Twitter Bot Tracks It” by Alexandria Symonds
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Ro Khanna Wants to Save Silicon Valley From Itself
description: The Democratic congressman’s new book is a striking manifesto for an age of digital anxiety.
content: It’s not often that you meet a member of Congress who is eager to discuss the German philosopher Jürgen Habermas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, Alan Feuer, Nick Corasaniti and Michael S. Schmidt
title: What the Trump Documents Might Tell the Jan. 6 Committee
description: Following last week’s Supreme Court ruling, the House panel has received material that it hopes could flesh out how the attack on the Capitol came about.
content: The National Archives has turned over to the House select committee investigating the assault on the Capitol last Jan. 6 a large batch of documents that former President Donald J. Trump had sought to keep out of the panel’s hands, citing executive privilege.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Gabriel Medina, Champion Surfer, Withdraws From Season to Focus on Mental Health
description: “I’m not in a place where I believe I can perform against the world’s best surfers right now,” the Brazilian three-time world champion said on Instagram.
content: Gabriel Medina, the No. 1-ranked world champion surfer, said on Monday that he would not compete in the 2022 World Surf League season and would instead focus on his mental health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: California Officials Ask Residents to Donate Blood Amid Severe Shortage
description: A Los Angeles hospital was forced to temporarily close its trauma center this month because it ran out of blood supplies.
content: Alongside the coronavirus pandemic is another, lesser-known problem that has forced hospitals to temporarily close their doors and health care workers to make impossible decisions about whom to treat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Sondheim’s ‘Assassins’ Ends Run Early Because of Coronavirus Cases
description: The sold-out production had been scheduled to run through Jan. 30, but decided to cancel its few remaining performances.
content: The Classic Stage Company’s production of “Assassins,” the Stephen Sondheim and John Weidman musical, became the latest show to cut its run short because of the coronavirus, announcing Tuesday that it would cancel its remaining performances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Why Is North Korea Suddenly Launching So Many Missiles?
description: Experience has shown Kim Jong-un that saber-rattling is the best way to get Washington’s attention, especially when global affairs are already in a precarious state.
content: SEOUL — North Korea began the new year by convening a meeting for the ruling Workers’ Party during which very little was said about the United States. That ominous silence didn’t last long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: Worried About the Health of Cinema? Sundance Has Good News for You.
description: From surprising found-footage documentaries to “Get Out”-influenced dramas and that Lena Dunham title, this year’s virtual festival has a lot to like.
content: There was a time not so long ago when the Sundance Film Festival was in danger of being overwhelmed by swag, hype and other extra-cinematic preoccupations. One year, if I remember right, there were stickers all over its Park City, Utah, home reminding those of us in attendance to “focus on films” rather than parties, celebrity sightings, industry buzz and tabloid gossip.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘An Invitation to His Bed’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: His freshman year of high school, my brother, Fred, walked out into a Massachusetts snowstorm with no shoes on. Tensions were too high at home for him to consider footwear. I ran after him with a pair of sports slides. We walked — first with me trailing behind, eventually arm in arm, and then finally back home. Twelve years later, we were grown. My husband left me when I was already depressed. As I sobbed in my car, unable to drive, my brother walked two miles to sit beside me in the passenger seat. Some people are siblings; we are co-pilots. — Gwendolyn Coburn
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Larry Diamond
title: Democrats, Want to Defend Democracy? Embrace What Is Possible.
description: Why Congress should reform the Electoral Count Act.
content: Like many scholars of democracy, I have strongly supported both the John Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act and the Freedom to Vote Act. Both are necessary (though not sufficient) to secure the most precious rights in any democracy — the right to vote and the right to have one’s vote counted fairly and accurately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezekiel J. Emanuel and Michael T. Osterholm
title: China’s Zero-Covid Policy Is a Pandemic Waiting to Happen
description: The planet’s most populous nation cannot seal itself off from the world forever.
content: As some 3,000 athletes, their retinues and the media converge on Beijing, the Chinese government has gone to extraordinary lengths to prevent the 24th version of the Winter Olympics, which open Feb. 4, from becoming a Covid superspreading event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: OSHA withdraws its workplace vaccine rule.
description: In pulling the rule, the Biden administration acknowledged what most businesses expected: the plan to make companies mandate vaccines-or-tests is over.
content: The Biden administration is withdrawing its requirement that large employers mandate workers be vaccinated or regularly tested, the Labor Department said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Fondren and Karen Zraick
title: What New York Dog Owners Should Know About Leptospirosis
description: The Health Department did not confirm reports of an outbreak of the bacterial disease linked to McCarren Park, but said it was working with the Parks Department to keep out the rats that spread the illness.
content: Alarm has grown among some New York City dog owners in recent days as reports have circulated about the risks to canine health posed by the city’s legions of rats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Can I Reveal a Colleague’s Covid Diagnosis?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to keep a coworker’s illness confidential, outing an unvaccinated colleague — and more.
content: I work in an office with cubicles six feet apart, but we are all up and about throughout the day. We are supposed to wear a mask every time we step outside our cubicles, but for short interactions that often does not happen. The C.D.C. says the risk is higher if people are within six feet of one another for a total of 15 minutes in a day. That is probably the case for all of us. My closest cubicle mate is unvaccinated and came down with Covid. He did not tell anyone, but I found out, and I am furious that he exposed me and did not tell me. He is now out on quarantine, having told others it was a different illness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tell Us: Are Rising Prices in Britain Affecting You?
description: The New York Times would like to hear from people in Britain who are affected by rising prices and are making changes to their spending habits because of inflation or in anticipation of higher energy bills and taxes.
content: The inflation rate in Britain is at its highest in 30 years, and isn’t expected to peak for several more months. Two-thirds of adults have said their cost of living has increased in the past month, according to the Office for National Statistics. Household budgets are facing a squeeze that is only likely to get worse when energy bills jump and tax increases are introduced in the spring.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Ruth Ozeki
description: A conversation with the novelist and Zen priest.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Ruth Ozeki. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Live Webinar: Teaching Science With The New York Times
description: Join us on Feb. 10 to hear how science educators find and use Times coverage to connect their subject areas to current events.
content: From climate change and genetic engineering to space exploration and vaccine efficacy, science topics are at the heart of many of today’s biggest news stories. In this webinar, science educators will discuss how they use New York Times reporting and multimedia to connect their classrooms to the current events shaping our world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Charlie Savage
title: C.I.A.-Backed Afghan Fighters Are Still Waiting to Reach U.S.
description: Commandos who played a key role in helping American forces are waiting for visas in the United Arab Emirates, and are among the last of the evacuated Afghans to get a chance to reach the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — During the frantic evacuation from Afghanistan in August, the American troops securing the Kabul airport against suicide bombers and other dangers were not alone. At the direction of the C.I.A., agency-trained Afghan counterterrorism squads helped patrol the perimeter, secure the gates and get American citizens through them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Grace Ashford
title: New York State’s mask policy is back in effect after a judge grants a stay.
description: A state judge had ruled against the mask mandate late Monday, arguing that Gov. Kathy Hochul lacked the authority to enact it.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — New York State’s indoor mask mandate will remain in effect after an appeals court judge on Tuesday temporarily blocked a lower-court ruling from a day before that had abruptly struck down the rule and created confusion across schools and businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: G.M. will spend $7 billion on Michigan plants to further its electric-vehicle aims.
description: The automaker will build a battery plant and overhaul an existing factory to produce electric pickup trucks, creating 4,000 jobs.
content: General Motors said Tuesday that it would spend $7 billion to build a battery plant in Michigan and overhaul an existing factory outside Detroit to begin producing electric pickup trucks by 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Caldwell
title: This Poll Shows Just How Much Trouble Democrats Are In
description: New Gallup numbers may portend a political earthquake.
content: According to the Gallup organization, 47 percent of Americans now identify with the Republican Party and 42 percent with the Democrats. That sounds ho-hum: one party doing a tad better than the other. But the Gallup numbers may portend a political earthquake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Russia, Stock Market, Australian Open: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Kazakhstan’s Longtime Leader Is Gone, but Still Seemingly Everywhere
description: Nursultan Nazarbayev, the autocratic former president, all but vanished after violent protests this month. But with his legacy so pervasive, will anything change?
content: NUR-SULTAN, Kazakhstan — For three decades, Nursultan Nazarbayev was seemingly everywhere in Kazakhstan, the country he ruled with an autocrat’s clenched fist. The capital’s airport was named after him, as were the city’s best university, a group of elite high schools throughout the country, well-endowed foundations and wide boulevards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: What Happens if Russia Cuts Off Europe’s Natural Gas?
description: Europe is a huge customer of Russia’s fossil fuels. Gas from the U.S. and elsewhere is helping offset fears of a midwinter cutoff.
content: While Russia masses troops and military equipment near its border with Ukraine, parallel tensions have been building in world energy markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Elton John shows are postponed as he tests positive for the coronavirus.
description: He is fully vaccinated and has had his booster shot and is experiencing mild symptoms, a Dallas venue announced as it postponed two concerts.
content: A pair of Elton John concerts at the American Airlines Center in Dallas have been postponed because the singer recently tested positive for the coronavirus, the venue said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Kitamura
title: ‘Notes on an Execution’ Isn’t Your Typical Serial Killer Novel
description: Danya Kukafka’s book focuses less on the mythos of the murderer and more on the humanity of his victims.
content: NOTES ON AN EXECUTIONBy Danya Kukafka
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Schulz
title: How to Make Sense of Our Covid Losses, Big and Small
description: What losing my father taught me about the pandemic.
content: I have a ghost calendar for the last two years. An eerie anti-diary, of a kind you surely have as well, it records what didn’t happen: a family Thanksgiving, never before missed; a Jason Isbell concert, postponed and rescheduled and then finally canceled; some work travels out West; a wedding I was meant to attend in May 2020 and then August 2020 and then June 2021. For two years now, the future as we envisioned it has been steadily fading away in front of us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: With One More Walk-Off, Big Papi Trots Into Cooperstown
description: A big man with a bigger personality, David Ortiz led the Red Sox to three World Series titles. Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens failed to gain election on their final writers’ ballot.
content: The David Ortiz Bridge, on Brookline Ave., above the Mass Pike, connects the Fenway Park neighborhood to Kenmore Square in Boston. From there it’s about four hours to Cooperstown, N.Y., soon to be home to another lasting marker of Ortiz’s outsize legacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: What Does It Mean to Be ‘Done With Covid’?
description: While the pandemic rages, normality isn’t an option.
content: On Saturday, several days after my son stopped testing positive for the coronavirus, I took him out for ramen and then to the movies. The theater was about half-full; it required masks but also served food and cocktails, which you could, obviously, unmask to consume. I wouldn’t have gone three weeks ago, when Omicron was at its height and my family hadn’t been infected yet. But now everyone in my household except me has had it — I’ve been protected by either dumb luck or my Moderna booster — and so, in my own life, the stakes of a positive test have gone down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang and John Liu
title: How Australia’s Leader Lost Control of His Chinese Social Media Account
description: A Chinese electronics company said it had bought the WeChat account legitimately, but some Australian officials said it was hijacked, and urged a boycott.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — When Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia opened his public WeChat account in 2019, it was during the lead-up to a federal election. He said it would allow him to directly communicate with Chinese-Australians and better understand the issues that concerned them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Catie Edmondson
title: Commerce Dept. Survey Uncovers ‘Alarming’ Chip Shortages
description: Increased demand for the semiconductors that power cars, electronics and electrical grids have stoked inflation and could cause more factory shutdowns in the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States is facing an “alarming” shortage of semiconductors, a government survey of more than 150 companies that make and buy chips found; the situation is threatening American factory production and helping to fuel inflation, Gina M. Raimondo, the commerce secretary, said in an interview on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Breezy Johnson, U.S. Medal Hopeful in Downhill, Will Miss Olympics
description: Johnson has crashed in training twice this month, leaving her with a battered knee. Her withdrawal means the field is wide open for the women’s downhill on Feb. 15.
content: The American ski racer Breezy Johnson, a top contender for a gold medal at next month’s Beijing Olympics in the women’s downhill, said on Monday that she would not compete in the Games because of torn right knee cartilage she sustained in the second of two high-speed training crashes this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pierre-Antoine Louis
title: Cannabis Events Come Out of Hiding in New York City
description: As New Yorkers wait for marijuana sales to be legalized, some small businesses are putting down roots.
content: New York may have legalized recreational marijuana in 2021, but the state still has not passed the laws that would allow its sale in stores, or its consumption at club-like lounges — moves that would open doors for a potential $4.2 billion industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: They Need Legal Advice on Debts. Should It Have to Come From Lawyers?
description: A nonprofit has filed a lawsuit in New York, hoping to clear the way for volunteers to help people defend themselves against debt collection suits.
content: The Rev. John Udo-Okon, a Pentecostal minister in the Bronx, has a lot of congregants who are sued by debt collectors and don’t know what to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Heavy Snow Strands Motorists in Greece and Turkey
description: In areas more used to dealing with extreme heat, blizzard conditions caused chaos on roads and at airports.
content: ATHENS — A rare heavy snowfall in the Mediterranean had emergency services scrambling on Tuesday to rescue people stranded in their cars, some for more than 20 hours, and caused transportation chaos and power outages in Greece and Turkey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Frank Dutton, Detective Who Took On Apartheid Crimes, Dies at 72
description: A lauded South Africa police official, he dug into cold cases from the days of white rule. “The finest detective that this country has ever produced.”
content: Frank Dutton, whose investigations into some of the biggest criminal cases in South African history, from apartheid-era hit squads to more recent high-level government corruption, earned him a reputation as his country’s greatest police detective, died on Jan. 20 at a hospital in Hillcrest, South Africa. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Wall Street’s swings continue as investors agonize over the Fed’s next move.
description: The S&P 500 fell nearly 3 percent before bouncing back somewhat in a second day of turbulent trading.
content: Wall Street’s dizzying swings continued for a second day on Tuesday, again driven by uncertainty about what the Federal Reserve might reveal on Wednesday after its first policy-setting meeting of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Kate Conger and Brian X. Chen
title: Google introduces a new system for tracking Chrome browser users.
description: The company is scrapping another plan that would have blocked so-called cookies after privacy groups and regulators complained that Google needed to do more to ensure privacy.
content: When Google announced a plan to block digital tracking cookies from its Chrome web browser two years ago, the advertising industry and regulators worried that the proposal would further entrench the search giant’s dominance over online ads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Markovits
title: They Left a Broken U.S. for Outer Space. Now They’re Coming Back.
description: Tochi Onyebuchi’s novel “Goliath” imagines what gentrification might look like in a nearly uninhabitable future America.
content: GOLIATHBy Tochi Onyebuchi
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: With Nightmares and Tears, a Kentucky Town Feels the Long Reach of a Tornado’s Trauma
description: The physical toll on Mayfield, Ky., is evident. The psychological anguish will be equally difficult to overcome.
content: MAYFIELD, Ky. — Isaiah Holt passes his days sequestered in a home that was not touched by the tornado. Still, he cannot escape the storm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: John Stamos on Bob Saget and the Many Stages of Their Friendship
description: In an interview, the “Full House” star recalls everything from early clashes to Cyrano-like support, as well as the last time he saw his former co-star.
content: When the stand-up comic and actor Bob Saget died on Jan. 9 at 65, stunned friends and family responded with an outpouring of tributes — among them, John Stamos, Saget’s co-star on “Full House” and the Netflix sequel “Fuller House,” and his longtime friend. In a video interview on Monday from his home in Los Angeles, Stamos reminisced about how what began as a sometimes fractious working relationship developed into a love for the ages. These are edited excerpts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Besonen
title: After a Fire Gutted Their Special Store, Customers Rallied to Save It
description: Essex Card Shop, known for its spiritually positive manager and niche inventory, has a devoted clientele.
content: It was a typical Monday afternoon at the Essex Card Shop, an encyclopedic stationery store in Manhattan’s East Village. Business had been steady. Jayant Patel, the 80-year-old manager, had just noticed a teenager wandering around, before being hustled out by an older woman, perhaps his grandmother. Now the store was empty, the dutiful manager at his post, behind the counter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
title: Alabama Redistricting Ruling Sparks Hopes for Democrats
description: Three federal judges in Alabama ruled that a new congressional map drawn by G.O.P. state lawmakers violated the Voting Rights Act.
content: After years of court decisions battering the Voting Rights Act, a ruling in an Alabama redistricting case is reasserting the power of the 56-year-old law — and giving Democrats and civil rights groups hope for beating back gerrymandered maps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: They Broke Up With Two Architects Before Finding the Right One
description: ‘It’s like going through bad relationships,’ said an owner of the 1975 Bay Area home. ‘The house needed an architect who wasn’t so driven by ego.’
content: When Gagan and Jasmin Arneja bought a Bay Area hillside home designed in 1975, they knew it would need some work. But with big windows offering expansive views over San Francisco and an interior lined with distinctive redwood-plywood paneling, there was already a lot about the house they liked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Caught on a Hot Mic: Biden Uses a Vulgarity to Insult a Fox News Reporter
description: The president later called Peter Doocy and “cleared the air,” Mr. Doocy said.
content: Aides to President Biden like to say he is transparent with the reporters who cover him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Rafael Nadal Prevails After Five Sets and Charge of Favoritism
description: Nadal beat Denis Shapovalov to reach the semifinals, then rejected his opponent’s complaints about unfairness, saying, “I think he’s wrong.”
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — After missing the game he has long played with such passion, Rafael Nadal has had ample opportunity to get reacquainted with tennis at this Australian Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Berkshire Hathaway plans to hold its next annual meeting in person.
description: The event is scheduled for April 30, a decision that reflects evolving, and sometimes diverging, approaches to live events in the pandemic.
content: Warren E. Buffett’s faithful followers will soon be able to meet face to face at the “Woodstock for Capitalists” again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Nearly Two Dozen Charged in Fraud Ring That Staged Car Crashes, U.S. Says
description: The elaborate scheme, which took place from 2017 to 2020 in Washington State, cost insurers $1 million, the authorities said.
content: The collisions often took place at night on desolate roads, investigators said: that way there would be no witnesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Police Say They Are Investigating Downing Street Lockdown Parties
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has come under fire over revelations that he and his staff attended parties while the country was in a coronavirus lockdown.
content: LONDON — The British police have opened an investigation into parties held at 10 Downing Street and other government offices during the coronavirus lockdown, an ominous development for Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who is trying to stave off a career-threatening challenge to his leadership over his handling of the scandal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Armstrong
title: Piecing Together God’s Body, From Head to Toe
description: In “God: An Anatomy,” Francesca Stavrakopoulou attempts to understand divinity as our ancestors did, as having a corporeal presence.
content: GODAn AnatomyBy Francesca Stavrakopoulou
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Court Throws Out Alabama’s New Congressional Map
description: A federal panel of judges ordered state lawmakers to redraw the lines, saying Black voters “have less opportunity than other Alabamians” to elect candidates of their choice.
content: WASHINGTON — A panel of three federal judges threw out Alabama’s congressional map on Monday and ordered state lawmakers to draw a new one with two, rather than just one, districts that are likely to elect Black representatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: California leaders agree to once again require extra paid sick leave.
description: The agreement would reinstate a benefit passed by the state in 2021 that expired at the end of September.
content: California will require businesses to provide workers who are recovering from the coronavirus, or are caring for infected family members, with as much as two weeks of supplemental paid sick leave, under a deal announced on Tuesday by Gov. Gavin Newsom and legislative leaders in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: As West Warns of Russian Attack, Ukraine Sends Different Message
description: The ‘‘stay calm” posture has left analysts guessing about its leadership’s motivation, but some say that after eight years of war, the country simply calculates the risks differently.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Russia’s military buildup on the Ukrainian border is easy to see. Satellite images show ever-growing patches of snow-covered tanks expanding along the frontier, and a stream of Russian TikTok posts records the steady westerly crawl of trains carrying missile launchers, armor and troops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Was the Market Sell-Off Overdone?
description: Stocks recovered after a sharp drop, but they are looking shaky again.
content: So far, 2022 is off to a rocky start for the stock market. Yesterday, after an initial plunge in which stocks dropped as much as 4 percent — the biggest one-day drop in nearly a year — the market rallied and ended the day with a slight gain. At one point, the S&P 500 was in a correction, a decline of 10 percent from a recent peak, for the first time since the start of the pandemic. And then it wasn’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Guilty Pleasures
description: What bad habits are you trying to stop?
content: A Times article detailed one writer’s struggle to kick her diet cola habit. Have you ever struggled with giving up soft drinks, sweets or other guilty pleasures? Are there other bad habits you have tried (successfully or unsuccessfully) to quit? What tricks helped you stop? What obstacles prevented your success?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Saints’ Super Bowl Coach Who Fought N.F.L. Rules Steps Down
description: Sean Payton was the most successful coach in the New Orleans Saints’ franchise history, but he drew rebuke from the league over targeted tackling and fought the N.F.L. on rules.
content: New Orleans Saints head coach Sean Payton, who led the team to its only Super Bowl title and, with quarterback Drew Brees, created one of the N.F.L.’s most successful tandems, announced his retirement in a news conference on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: U.S. Navy Fighter Jet Accident in South China Sea Injures 7
description: The military said it was investigating the cause of a “landing mishap” during routine operations.
content: An accident aboard an aircraft carrier in the South China Sea injured seven American sailors and led to the pilot ejecting from his F-35 fighter jet on Monday, the Navy said in a statement, calling it a “landing mishap.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Beyond the Infinite Two Minutes’ Review: Hello, It’s You
description: In this time-travel comedy, a cafe owner and his friends discover a portal that allows them to see two minutes into the future.
content: More goofy than gripping, Junta Yamaguchi’s sci-fi farce, “Beyond the Infinite Two Minutes,” is a time-travel tale dotted with philosophical musings and romantic expectations. Yet however cleverly constructed and enthusiastically executed, this debut feature — shot on an iPhone in a single location — rarely surmounts the twistiness of its premise and the repetitiveness of its setups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins and Ashley Southall
title: 2nd N.Y.P.D. Officer Dies of Wounds From Harlem Shooting
description: Wilbert Mora, 27, joined the department in 2018. He and his partner, Jason Rivera, were killed by a man who opened fire during a domestic call, the police said.
content: As a student at John Jay College of Criminal Justice in 2018, the same year he joined the New York Police Department, Officer Wilbert Mora studied the effects of stop-and-frisk tactics and less confrontational strategies like community policing on neighborhoods like East Harlem, where he lived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: The Rise of the Crypto Mayors
description: This new political breed accepts paychecks in Bitcoin. The mayors also want to use buzzy new tech like NFTs to raise money for public projects.
content: Scott Conger, the mayor of Jackson, Tenn., campaigned on a modest promise to improve local infrastructure. He planned to build sidewalks, open a senior center and repair the aging storm-water disposal system in his city of 68,000, about halfway between Nashville and Memphis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: Leprosy Hospital Offers Healing, and a Haven, to the Shunned
description: While leprosy is now easily treated, those who have the disease are still often ostracized. But they’re always welcome at this refuge in India, a nation that records over half the world’s cases.
content: HYDERABAD, India — When Amina Begum stares at her hands, tears drop from her eyes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Sagal
title: It’s Just a Game. Or Is It?
description: In “Seven Games: A Human History,” Oliver Roeder presents a study of checkers, backgammon, chess, Go, poker, Scrabble and bridge — and asks why we play.
content: SEVEN GAMESA Human HistoryBy Oliver Roeder
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Germany Vaccine Mandate Brings Together Unlikely Coalition of Protesters
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 25, 2022.
content: “We were looking for the problem on the fringes of society, but it was always in our middle.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: Whitney Biennial Picks 63 Artists to Take Stock of Now
description: The influential exhibition, which opens in April, will lean toward the conceptual, with particular attention to Native artists and the U.S.-Mexico border.
content: Even in regular times, organizing the Whitney Biennial is a high-stakes project. The show is a barometer — anticipated and debated for the picture it proposes of tendencies in American art and their public relevance. Participation can turbocharge an artist’s career. The exhibition sometimes becomes a lightning rod for political controversy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Trevor Noah Blasts Robert Kennedy Jr. for Invoking Anne Frank
description: Noah said anti-vaxxers gathering to hear from Kennedy might have found him leaning too liberal for believing in the Holocaust.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: Mahershala Ali Finally Gets the Leading Role He Deserves
description: After a string of supporting performances, he steps into the spotlight as not one but two main characters in the sci-fi drama “Swan Song.”
content: In a more just world, Mahershala Ali, one of America’s most gifted actors, would have played the lead in at least a dozen films by now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tayari Jones
title: Searching for America, South of the Mason-Dixon
description: In “South to America: A Journey Below the Mason-Dixon to Understand the Soul of a Nation,” Imani Perry straddles genres to find her own — and our — South.
content: SOUTH TO AMERICAA Journey Below the Mason-Dixon to Understand the Soul of a NationBy Imani Perry
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Why Does Alcohol Mess With My Sleep?
description: Tips for getting a better night’s rest when your evening plans include drinking.
content: A couple of glasses of wine or a few drinks in the evening will probably make you fall asleep faster than normal. Who among us hasn’t left the dishes for the next morning or neglected a skin-care routine after a dinner party or festive night out?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Where Is Germany in the Ukraine Standoff? Its Allies Wonder.
description: Germany’s allies have begun to question what price Berlin is prepared to pay to deter Russia, and even its reliability as an ally, as it wavers on tough measures.
content: BERLIN — The United States and its NATO allies are moving to bulk up their military commitments in the Baltics and Eastern Europe as the standoff with Russia over Ukraine deepens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: War May Loom, but Are There Offramps?
description: Fears of a Russian invasion of Ukraine are growing, but diplomatic options remain.
content: WASHINGTON — Russian troops are encircling Ukraine from three sides. In Washington and Brussels, there are warnings of crushing sanctions if Vladimir V. Putin orders an invasion. Embassy families — both American and Russian — are being evacuated from Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: After Coup in Burkina Faso, Protesters Turn to Russia for Help
description: Fed up with the failure of their government, and France, to stop the violence caused by militants, some citizens now call for Russia to intervene.
content: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — The morning after the coup in Burkina Faso, a crowd of revelers celebrating the military takeover in the dusty main plaza of the capital had two messages for the outside world: No to France, and yes to Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: A fashion brand is fined for suppressing negative reviews, putting retailers on alert.
description: Fashion Nova held lower-starred reviews for approval before they could be posted, the F.T.C. said in a complaint.
content: Retailers may want to think twice before removing negative reviews from their websites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Mike Ives
title: An Australian aid ship with a Covid outbreak docks in Tonga.
description: Twenty-three people aboard the ship have tested positive for the virus, prompting concerns that it could spread to Tonga. The volcano-stricken island has reported only one case during the pandemic.
content: An Australian naval ship carrying aid supplies arrived in Tonga on Wednesday, a day after the Australian defense minister said that 23 people aboard the vessel had tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdullah Shihipar
title: Are Better Things Coming? Inshallah
description: Whatever language you speak, “inshallah” can bring you hope.
content: When I was growing up, my family used the expression “inshallah” a lot. For Muslims, the term — which translates to “If God wills” — is auspicious: If you want something to happen, you should say inshallah before you say anything else about it. The Quran says as much in its 18th chapter, Surah Al-Kahf. “And never say of anything, ‘Indeed, I will do that tomorrow,’ except [when adding], ‘If Allah wills.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By W. Caleb McDaniel
title: A Shipwreck Leads to a Reckoning
description: In “The Last Slave Ship,” Ben Raines tells the story of the Clotilda, the founding of Africatown, Ala., and a history that wouldn’t stay buried.
content: THE LAST SLAVE SHIPThe True Story of How Clotilda Was Found, Her Descendants, and an Extraordinary ReckoningBy Ben Raines
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Apple gets restraining order against a woman accused of stalking Tim Cook.
description: The woman, a 45-year-old Virginia resident, is accused of threatening Mr. Cook and visiting his home, according to the court documents.
content: A judge in Santa Clara County has granted Apple a temporary restraining order against a woman accused of stalking and threatening the company’s chief executive, Tim Cook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: New York Restaurant Won’t Face City Scrutiny for Admitting Sarah Palin
description: Elio’s let the former Alaska governor eat indoors despite a city rule that it ask for proof she was vaccinated. She wasn’t.
content: New York City will not investigate Elio’s, an Upper East Side restaurant, for allowing Sarah Palin to dine indoors on Saturday night without asking for proof that she had been vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 25, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Jan. 25, 2022.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the areas of Tonga that bore the brunt of the tsunami referred incorrectly to the areas that were hardest hit. The three islets of Mango, Fonoifua and Nomuka were most devastated by the tsunami, not Nomuka alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia’s Military Drills
description: The Kremlin blamed the U.S. for ramping up tensions.
content: Russia on Tuesday announced a flurry of military drills across its vast territory, spanning from the Pacific Ocean to its western flank near Ukraine. They include joint drills with the Chinese fleet in the Arabian Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: The Black List, Founded in Hollywood, Expands Into Theater
description: The project seeks to connect undiscovered writers with industry gatekeepers.
content: The Black List, an effort to boost the careers of undiscovered writers by drawing attention to high-quality unproduced scripts, was formed 17 years ago with a focus on Hollywood. Now the organization is looking to extend its work into theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Powell
title: How It Feels to Be an Asian Student in an Elite Public School
description: Stuyvesant, Brooklyn Tech and other schools across the country are under pressure to end entrance exams. Students have complicated feelings about that.
content: Tausifa Haque, a 17-year-old daughter of Bangladeshi immigrants, walks in the early morning from her family’s apartment in the Bronx to the elevated subway and rides south to Brooklyn, a journey of one and a half hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Slowdowns in the U.S. and China will hold back global growth, a report says.
description: The International Monetary Fund forecasts that the growth rate of the world economy will slow to 4.4 percent in 2022.
content: Slowdowns in the world’s two biggest economies — the United States and China — are likely to be larger than expected this year, dragging down output on every continent and reducing global growth, a new report warned on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisa Gabbert
title: The Lyric Decision: How Poets Figure Out What Comes Next
description: There are endless ways to write a poem, but Rilke offered one foolproof formula that echoes throughout several recent collections.
content: The poet Andrew Weatherhead once tweeted, “The best way to read a poem is to pretend each line is the name of a horse; so the poem is just a list of horses.” This joke says something serious about poetry. It calls attention to the line as a fundamental unit, which in some sense always stands alone — the next line could always be anything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Harris
title: After a Mastectomy, Moving Between Gratitude and Grief
description: Getting diagnosed with a breast cancer gene mutation at 32 was a gift, but left room for disappointment too.
content: I lay on my back and opened my robe, just as I’d done for every other appointment. But when the doctor prodded my new breasts with her fingertips, I felt naked for the first time. Thin, sloping scars were exposed on my chest, where a surgeon had removed my nipples, but left a smaller version of my areolas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Passionate Learners
description: Ray Brunsberg and Ellen Brunsberg make their playful debut.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to the husband-and-wife constructing duo Ray and Ellen Brunsberg on making their New York Times Crossword debuts together today!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Get Through a Power Outage
description: Be proactive before things go dark. Never use a gas stove or oven as an indoor heater.
content: “Try to consume your perishables right away,” says Ruth Santiago, an environmental lawyer from Salinas, Puerto Rico, who lost electricity for nearly two months after Hurricane Maria hit the island in September 2017. Fishermen sometimes paid Santiago in fish for her legal services. After she lost power, she emptied her freezer and cooked a big seafood stew to share with neighbors. Your freezer will keep its temperature for about 48 hours. If you have forewarning and sufficient space, put water bottles in your freezer and refrigerator to help extend cooler temperatures. Prepare by keeping stores of canned food, bottled water, flashlights, solar lamps and cellphone chargers. Make use of the sun; Santiago took to brewing tea in a jar set outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Justin Peck and Collaborators Combine Gravitational Universes
description: For his new work at New York City Ballet, Peck enlisted the composer Caroline Shaw and the artist Eva LeWitt: “It has really felt like a back-and-forth conversation.”
content: A few months ago, Justin Peck, the resident choreographer of New York City Ballet, was entertaining his baby daughter with a set of building blocks as he listened to the first movement of Caroline Shaw’s a cappella “Partita for 8 Voices.” He was thinking about how to approach the densely packed music, layered with speech, vocal effects and wordless harmonies, when he noticed that his daughter’s toy set contained eight shapes. Together, they began to move the shapes around to the music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Madison Keys Powers Her Way Into Australian Open Semifinals
description: The unseeded American upset No. 4 Barbora Krejcikova to advance to the semifinals, where she will face No. 1 Asheligh Barty.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Before Madison Keys plays a match, her new coach Georgi Rumenov likes to remind her that “there is no need to, there is no have to.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: For Ukrainian Soldiers, a Nervous Guessing Game on the Front
description: Given Russia’s penchant for misdirection, it’s unclear how a military incursion would start. And that keeps the Ukrainian troops on edge.
content: SVITLODARSK, Ukraine — The Ukrainian soldiers watch and wait, nervously peering through a periscope from an icy trench at a forward observation post in eastern Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Two Covid Americas
description: The unvaccinated are less worried than the boosted, according to a poll.
content: Covid’s starkly different impact on the young and old has been one of the virus’s defining characteristics. It tends to be mild for children and younger adults but is often severe for the elderly. More than three-quarters of all U.S. Covid deaths have occurred among people 65 and older.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alida Becker
title: Historical Novels About Aviators, Heroes and Old-Fashioned Problem Solvers
description: From prewar Europe to Nazi-occupied France to Tudor England, this trio of novels will pilot you to different (and equally complicated) times.
content: The famed writer and aviator Antoine de Saint-Exupéry may be the title character in Antonio Iturbe’s THE PRINCE OF THE SKIES (Feiwel & Friends/Macmillan, 544 pp., $28.99), but his camaraderie with two other pioneering French pilots is what gets this novel airborne. That and its celebration of the sheer joy of flying — of the raucous adventure of living in an era when “aviation isn’t an industry; it’s just the audacity of a few reckless entrepreneurs.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: kindle
description: This word has appeared in 35 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Neil Young posts and removes a letter demanding Spotify remove his music.
description: “They can have Rogan or Young,” Neil Young wrote to his management team and record label in a letter that he has since removed from his website, according to Rolling Stone. “Not both.”
content: A letter briefly appeared on Monday on Neil Young’s website that asked to remove his music from Spotify, according to Rolling Stone, in protest of the platform’s streaming of the podcaster Joe Rogan, who has been dismissive of the coronavirus vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Striver, Burnout, Lover, Scrub: A Debut Novelist Lays It Bare
description: “Fuccboi,” by Sean Thor Conroe, follows a sometimes-tender, sometimes-offensive delivery boy struggling to produce meaningful art.
content: FUCCBOIBy Sean Thor Conroe
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: What We Gain by Enchanting the Objects in Our Lives
description: The novelist and Zen Buddhist priest Ruth Ozeki draws connections between meditation, writing and the art and practice of listening.
content: The world has gotten louder, even when we’re alone. A day spent in isolation can still mean a day buffeted by the voices on social media and the news, on podcasts, in emails and text messages. Objects have also gotten louder: through the advertisements that follow us around the web, the endless scroll of merchandise available on internet shopping sites and in the plentiful aisles of superstores. What happens when you really start listening to all these voices? What happens when you can’t stop hearing them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: The Omicron Olympics
description: The variant may pose the biggest test yet for China’s strict “zero Covid” precautions.
content: The combination of the Winter Olympics and Omicron may pose the biggest test yet for China’s strict “zero Covid” precautions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Right Way to Stop Rising Crime in New York
description: Getting crime under control is critical to New York City’s revival.
content: In recent days in New York, a woman was shoved to her death from a subway platform. A baby was hit by a stray bullet in the face. A police officer was fatally shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joey Roulette
title: Japanese Company Joins March Back to the Moon in 2022
description: Before the end of the year, ispace aims to place a lander with two small rovers on the lunar surface. It may find other visitors have also made the trip this year.
content: A Japanese company is pushing ahead with plans to launch a private moon lander by the end of 2022, a year packed with other moonshot ambitions and rehearsals that could foretell how soon humans get back to the lunar surface.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel, Lisa Lerer and Jennifer Medina
title: With Some Voters ‘Ready to Move On,’ Democrats Search for New Message on Virus
description: Democrats were cheered for strict lockdowns and pandemic precautions. Now many weary voters want to hear the party’s plan for living with the coronavirus.
content: When the coronavirus pandemic first swept Pennsylvania, Gov. Tom Wolf closed stores and schools and ordered millions of citizens to stay home. Even four months into the crisis in 2020, all but “life-sustaining” businesses in much of the state were locked down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Inflation and the Power of Narrative
description: Why people are so down on the economy, revisited.
content: President Biden had what I’d call a human moment yesterday. After a Fox News correspondent shouted out a question about whether inflation would be a political liability, Biden could be heard muttering: “No, it’s a great asset. More inflation. What a stupid son of a bitch.” Seriously, can you blame him?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: In a Georgia County, Deep Distrust Over a Plan to Close Polling Places
description: As legislation to expand voting rights was blocked in Washington, local residents debate a plan from officials in Lincoln County, Ga., who say they want to streamline and modernize their system.
content: LINCOLN COUNTY, Ga. — The showdown over voting rights in the U.S. Senate may be over for now. But the issue is still smoldering in a stretch of Northeast Georgia countryside where local officials recently introduced a plan to close seven polling sites and consolidate them into one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Attack of the Right-Wing Thought Police
description: Don’t teach anything that makes students uncomfortable.
content: Americans like to think of their nation as a beacon of freedom. And despite all the ways in which we have failed to live up to our self-image, above all the vast injustices that sprang from the original sin of slavery, freedom — not just free elections, but also freedom of speech and thought — has long been a key element of the American idea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: A Throwback Game for the Big East
description: When Seton Hall played St. John’s on Monday night on its campus, a crowd of mostly students got a taste of the glory days of the Big East Conference.
content: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J. — Back in the Big East Conference’s formative years, when Georgetown, Syracuse, St. John’s, Villanova and their brethren were just getting to develop enmity toward one another, men’s basketball games were still played in rickety band boxes with warped floors, frothy fans and a regular exchange of sharp elbows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: U.S. to Bolster Europe’s Fuel Supply to Blunt Threat of Russian Cutoff
description: Many European officials suspect President Vladimir V. Putin instigated the crisis in the winter in part to leverage his threat to turn off Russian fuel sales to Europe.
content: The Biden administration announced on Tuesday that it was working with gas and crude oil suppliers from the Middle East, North Africa and Asia to bolster supplies to Europe in the coming weeks, in an effort to blunt the threat that Russia could cut off fuel shipments in the escalating conflict over Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: ‘We Are Going to Turn Our Pain Into Purpose’
description: Mayor Eric Adams’s ambitious gun safety plan includes reviving a controversial police unit his predecessor disbanded.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at Mayor Eric Adams’s “Blueprint to End Gun Violence.” We’ll also look at a pleasantly retro sculpture with a one-word message: “Hopeful.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diego Bragà
title: What My Queer Uncle Taught Me About How to Live
description: A beloved uncle left an inheritance made of love.
content: Historically, the queer community has not been portrayed in mainstream culture as being capable of protecting children and young people. Yet my uncle Ricardo, himself an openly gay man, was the ultimate guardian of my childhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alia Malek
title: A Historic Verdict, and a New Front in the Global Fight for Human Rights
description: The first time anyone from the Syrian regime is judged guilty of its crimes is in a German court. What justice does it bring to Syrians?
content: On the night of July 20, 2021, Ruham Hawash lay awake unsure of where she was, mistaking her hotel bed in Koblenz, Germany, for the cramped and filthy cell in Damascus where, in 2012, she was detained and brutalized. The next day, in a German court, she would see and testify against the Syrian colonel who oversaw her torture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Stay Woke. The Right Can Be Illiberal, Too.
description: Dis-enlightenment thinking isn’t exclusive to the left.
content: Those of us who sustainedly criticize the excesses of the Great Awokening are often told that we’re making a mountain out of a molehill. That the real problem is censorship not from the left but from the right. That censorship from the left is largely a matter of pile-ons by anonymous Twitter denizens or college kids expressing themselves, while censorship from the right involves menacing officials dedicated to eliminating, for instance, discussion of race in schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Put Down Your No. 2 Pencils. Forever.
description: The SAT will go completely digital by 2024 amid questions about whether college admissions tests are fair, or even necessary.
content: The SAT will soon be taken exclusively on a computer, the College Board announced on Tuesday, ending an era in which high schoolers have had to make sure their No. 2 pencils were sharpened and their answer bubbles were completely filled in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Jenna Ortega Gets Her Thrills From Radiohead and ‘Paris, Texas’
description: The scream queen talks about her latest film, “The Fallout” on HBO Max, dancing in public and driving in the dark.
content: There’s horror, and then there’s terror. Jenna Ortega now knows the difference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Microsoft’s profits continue to climb.
description: Profit and sales at the tech giant, the first of the largest tech companies to report earnings for the three months ending in December, grew about 20 percent.
content: Microsoft announced record profits and sales on Tuesday despite investor fears that the pandemic-fueled tech boom may be over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: New York Mask Mandate Back in Effect After Judge Grants Stay
description: An appeals court judge granted a motion to temporarily block a lower-court ruling that had struck down the state’s mask mandate.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — New York’s indoor mask mandate will remain in effect for now after an appeals court judge on Tuesday blocked a lower-court ruling from a day before that had abruptly struck down the policy and created confusion across schools and businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: M.L.B. and Its Players Union Show Some Movement in Lockout
description: The players formally rejected the league’s offer — they didn’t believe some of M.L.B.’s ideas would accomplish what the league claimed — and made a counterproposal.
content: With spring training scheduled to begin in just over three weeks and the sides still far apart on a striking a new labor agreement, Major League Baseball and its players’ union met on Monday and made plans to gather again on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israeli experts recommend offering a fourth vaccine dose to people age 18 and over.
description: The Health Ministry cited early signs that a fourth shot might help protect against serious illness, but has yet to approve the panel’s recommendation.
content: JERUSALEM — A medical panel advising the Israeli government has recommended making fourth coronavirus vaccine doses available to people age 18 and over, the Health Ministry said on Tuesday, citing what it suggested were some early signs of the effectiveness of an additional shot in helping prevent serious illness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: U.S. troops may be deployed to Eastern Europe.
content: The Pentagon announced yesterday that it had put 8,500 American troops on “high alert” for possible deployment to Eastern Europe, as NATO and the U.S. braced for a possible Russian invasion of Ukraine. “It’s very clear the Russians have no intention right now of de-escalating,” John F. Kirby, the Pentagon spokesman, said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: He Was in Witness Protection in Maine. But His Harlem Life Kept Calling.
description: In Lewiston, Maine, a man who called himself Abraham helped his neighbors with the trash and rode dirt bikes with his friend. His old life in New York City got him killed.
content: It was 2016, and Abraham Rodriguez received a text message that made him light up. It was from his friend Nik Pappaconstantine, who had just picked up a new toy: a sleek, speedy dirt bike — perfect for back road riding in Lewiston, the small city in Maine where they lived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez and Jody García
title: Guatemala Sentences Former Fighters to 30 Years in Prison for Rape
description: Five members of a pro-government paramilitary group were convicted of crimes against humanity that were committed against five Indigenous women during the country’s civil war.
content: MEXICO CITY — A top Guatemalan court has sentenced five former paramilitary members to 30 years in prison for the rape of several Indigenous women in the early 1980s, during the nation’s long, bloody civil war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Have You Ever Jumped Into Ice-Cold Water?
description: Some people are drawn to cold-water swimming. They find it exhilarating, refreshing or even restorative. What do you think?
content: Have you seen athletes dip into an ice bath after a hard workout? Are you familiar with a polar bear plunge, when people celebrate New Year’s Day — or raise money for a charity — by swimming in a frigid lake or ocean? Do either of these activities appeal to you?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Russia Steps Up Propaganda War Amid Tensions With Ukraine
description: The disinformation campaign includes claims that NATO and Ukrainian forces are preparing to attack Russian speakers in Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — As the United States issued warnings last month about the Russian troops on Ukraine’s borders and President Biden threatened President Vladimir V. Putin with sanctions if he launched an invasion, researchers noticed an uptick in social media posts accusing Ukraine of plotting a genocide against ethnic Russians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: On the Ground in Kazakhstan’s Capital
description: Our Moscow correspondent, Valerie Hopkins, visited Nur-Sultan to understand why the country erupted in  violent protests.
content: Our Moscow correspondent, Valerie Hopkins, visited Nur-Sultan to understand why the country erupted in  violent protests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis and Jeremy Engle
title: Weekly News Quiz for Students: Ukraine Border, Viral Word Game, 5G
description: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
content: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Ana Ley
title: Why Doesn’t the N.Y.C. Subway Have Barriers?
description: Recent incidents where subway riders have been pushed onto the tracks have rekindled interest in platform barriers separating trains from riders. We took a look at a city that already is using them.
content: Recent incidents where subway riders have been pushed onto the tracks have rekindled interest in platform barriers separating trains from riders. We took a look at a city that already is using them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: How many stars are in the Milky Way galaxy?
description: The answer is many, many, many.
content: The answer is many, many, many.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Johnston
title: The U.S. Labor Movement Is Popular, Prominent and Also Shrinking
description: Approval of unions in the U.S. is the highest it’s been in decades, while participation in them has steadily fallen.
content: Approval of unions in the U.S. is the highest it’s been in decades, while participation in them has steadily fallen.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Bay Area Renovation With a Light Touch
description: “The house needed an architect who wasn’t so driven by ego,” said an owner of the 1975 Bay Area home, which was in need of an update.
content: “The house needed an architect who wasn’t so driven by ego,” said an owner of the 1975 Bay Area home, which was in need of an update.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diego Bragà
title: Think About the Beautiful Future Ahead
description: When a beloved uncle died, he left behind an inheritance made of love.
content: When a beloved uncle died, he left behind an inheritance made of love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: E.U. Leaders Vow ‘Consequences’ for Russian Aggression
description: President Emmanuel Macron of France and Chancellor Olaf Scholz warned that a Russian attack on Ukraine would lead to a serious response, though Germany’s economic ties have complicated its stance.
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France and Chancellor Olaf Scholz warned that a Russian attack on Ukraine would lead to a serious response, though Germany’s economic ties have complicated its stance.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Russia and Ukraine: How to Avoid a War
description: Differing views on how the U.S. should respond to the Russian threat of an invasion. Also: Listen to the children; the “business” of the royals.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
